terminologie_extrait.definition: The opponent’s playing elbow, the midpoint between the forehand and backhand; target slightly toward forehand if opponent is close, slightly toward backhand if opponent is off the table.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Used as the primary placement to force indecision between forehand and backhand.

play_the_middle.probleme: Failing to attack the opponent’s middle to create indecision.
causes_communes: Hitting repeatedly to forehand or backhand instead of the playing elbow.
Not going wide when choosing to play forehand/backhand corners.
Playing without enough aggression to pressure decision time.

debutant: Aim aggressive shots to the opponent’s playing elbow (middle) to force a forehand/backhand choice.
If choosing corners, place balls wide to stretch angles.
intermediaire: Adjust middle placement based on opponent distance: slightly to forehand if close; slightly to backhand if off the table.
Maintain assertive pace so the opponent has minimal time to choose a wing.
avance: Blend middle attacks with occasional wide balls to create maximum uncertainty while preventing rhythm.

exercices_complementaires.description: Rally while aiming every ball at opponent’s playing elbow; if opponent moves close, bias slightly to forehand; if off table, bias slightly to backhand; keep strokes aggressive.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: table; bucket of balls; practice partner

exercices_complementaires.description: Play one ball wide (forehand or backhand), then immediately to the middle to force indecision under time pressure.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: table; bucket of balls; practice partner

erreurs_a_eviter: Feeding comfortable forehand/backhand rallies by avoiding the middle.
Playing to corners without sufficient width.
Placing to the middle passively without pace.

meta.article_title: Tactics for the Slow of Foot: How to Play a Faster Opponent

tactics_for_the_slow_of_foot_how_to_play.probleme: Struggling to compete against a faster, more mobile opponent.
causes_communes: Starting to backhand first and giving opponent two forehands in a row.
Predictable placement that lets opponent step around early.
Allowing opponent to initiate with loops due to long/loose serves and pushes.

debutant: Play to the wide forehand first, then switch to backhand to prevent two-step-around forehands.
Develop a reliable backhand to reduce movement needs.
Serve short and push short to stop the opponent from looping.
intermediaire: Anticipate common returns when serving and move early based on patterns.
Use a fast down-the-line serve to catch early step-arounds.
Heavy push, then quick block to rush the opponent and force errors.
avance: Exploit wide-angle play beyond the corners to increase movement distance.
Alternate quick off-the-bounce pushes with quick blocks to compound time pressure.

exercices_complementaires.description: Feed to wide forehand; receiver returns to backhand; repeat pattern to practice FH-first then BH switch.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: table; practice partner; bucket of balls

exercices_complementaires.description: Receiver gives heavy backspin; attacker loops softly; blocker practices immediate quick block to wide corner.
Alternate serving short and pushing short; goal is to keep ball low/short to prevent loops.
Server practices sudden fast serves to wide forehand to catch early step-arounds.

erreurs_a_eviter: Opening to the backhand first and conceding two forehands to the opponent.
Narrow angles that minimize opponent’s movement.
Serving/pushing long routinely and allowing easy loops.

meta.article_title: How To Play Wildly-Attacking Junior Players

how_to_play_wildly_attacking_junior_play.probleme: Trouble handling juniors who attack wildly with speed and quickness.
causes_communes: Letting the junior establish a speed-based rhythm.
Playing too passive and offering easy attack balls.
Predictable attacks and placements.

debutant: Open rallies with steady, aggressive shots (e.g., loop) instead of wild swings.
Use ball control with variation when not attacking; make pushes heavy and deep.
intermediaire: Vary speed, depth, spin, and direction on attacks; include down-the-line and sharp angles.
Choose which balls the junior gets to attack; avoid giving easy rhythm balls.
Use lobbing/defense with variation only as needed; continue to vary to prevent rhythm.
avance: Exploit juniors’ reduced reach with aggressive angles, especially versus smaller/younger players.
Maintain tactical discipline under pressure; avoid turning rallies into pure speed contests.

exercices_complementaires.description: Initiate points with consistent opening loops of varied spin, speed, and direction; partner attempts counterattacks.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: table; bucket of balls; practice partner

exercices_complementaires.description: Alternate heavy-deep pushes with occasional no-spin/light pushes to set up higher returns.
Sequence attacks to wide angles and down-the-line to break rhythm and exploit reach.

erreurs_a_eviter: Engaging in a speed contest against a quicker opponent.
Predictable patterns that allow rhythm.
Playing too passively and conceding initiative.

coaching_between_games.probleme: Ineffective or overwhelming coaching during brief between-game breaks.
causes_communes: Ignoring the player’s emotional state (too tense or too lax).
Overloading with advice.
Focusing on complex rally plans instead of simple, executable items.

debutant: Assess and address emotional state first: calm the excitable; energize the lackadaisical.
Keep advice short: 1–2 items on serve, 1–2 on receive, 1 on rallying.
Use simple rally cues (e.g., stay close; BH-to-BH then down-the-line).
intermediaire: Provide general serves plus occasional surprise serves and clear follow-ups.
Give specific receive plans (e.g., loop long serves; push short serves quick to a side).
Combine tips coherently (serve pattern + expected receive + first attack).
avance: Self-coach between games using the same structure when no coach is present.

exercices_complementaires.description: Practice 60-second timeouts: identify emotional state, set 2 receive and 2 serve priorities, and 1 rally cue.
Write and practice two main serves with planned follow-ups plus one surprise serve to be used sparingly.

erreurs_a_eviter: Talking too much and confusing the player.
Failing to manage emotions before tactics.
Providing only rally advice without clear serve/receive priorities.

closing_out_a_match.probleme: Choosing effective serves at the end of a close match.
causes_communes: Relying on surprise serves that either win outright or hand over initiative.
Not knowing which serves set up your strengths against this specific opponent.
Tension preventing relaxed execution.

debutant: Learn to stay relaxed in pressure moments (sports psychology noted as prerequisite).
Use serves that reliably set up your preferred follow-ups (e.g., serve backspin then loop a long push).
intermediaire: Employ surprise serves sparingly; expect that stronger opponents are less often surprised.
Identify during the match which serves draw the returns you want and repeat them late.
avance: Trust your best serve–follow patterns under pressure and execute confidently.

exercices_complementaires.description: Simulate deuce/close-score situations and practice primary serve–follow patterns; add occasional surprise serve attempts.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: table; bucket of balls; practice partner

erreurs_a_eviter: Overusing surprise serves.
Choosing serves without a planned follow-up.
Letting nerves dictate poor decisions.

terminologie_extrait.definition: The server serves, the opponent receives, and the server attacks.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Typically serve short backspin, receive is a long push, and the server loops.

terminologie_extrait.definition: Server serves, receiver returns; server attacks to set up a put-away; receiver returns the attack; server attacks again to end the point.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Often serve short backspin, loop third ball, then smash or loop-kill the fifth after a block.

fifth_ball_attack.probleme: Missing the fifth ball after opening against backspin.
fifth_ball_attack.diagnostic: Players often drop the back shoulder again and are rushed by a faster fifth-ball block.
causes_communes: Back shoulder lowered on the fifth ball as if lifting backspin.
Incoming fifth ball is faster than the third ball, causing rushed strokes.
Trying to end points on the third ball instead of using it to set up the fifth.

debutant: When looping backspin (third ball), drop the back shoulder; on the fifth ball versus a block, keep the shoulder up.
Use the third-ball loop as a controlled offensive shot to set up a weaker fifth ball.
intermediaire: Prioritize placement on put-aways: wide angles or the opponent’s elbow.
If a hard third-ball rip comes back quickly, step back and loop the next ball with control.
avance: Blend spin, depth, and placement on the third ball to elicit a predictable block you can finish.
Choose smash or loop-kill on the fifth based on quality of block and position.

exercices_complementaires.description: Serve short backspin; partner pushes long; player loops with dropped shoulder; partner blocks; player attacks fifth with shoulder up (smash or loop-kill).
exercices_complementaires.materiel: table; bucket of balls; practice partner

exercices_complementaires.description: After a controlled third-ball loop, aim fifth-ball finishes to wide corners or opponent’s elbow.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: table; markers or imagined targets; practice partner

erreurs_a_eviter: Lowering the back shoulder on the fifth ball.
Overhitting the fifth ball without setup and placement.
Always trying to rip the third ball instead of building the point.

terminologie_extrait.definition: How you develop your game (e.g., building serves to set up your loop) during ongoing practice and development.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Developmental stage; never ends as long as you practice.

terminologie_extrait.definition: How you use what you have to win specific matches.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Choosing options in a given match based on current strengths/weaknesses.

strategic_versus_tactical_thinking.probleme: Confusing strategic development with tactical match play.
causes_communes: Lacking practice plans to fix weaknesses that limit tactical choices.
Expecting tactical solutions without developed weapons.

debutant: Identify a weakness that limits tactical choices (e.g., forehand vs. backspin) and practice it strategically.
In matches, choose between available options (e.g., controlled attack or push) based on current ability.
intermediaire: Align practice (strategy) to create weapons that enable more tactical options.
Prepare opponent-specific serve/receive plans tactically using developed skills.
avance: Continuously audit whether strategic training is delivering the tools needed for tactical execution.

exercices_complementaires.description: List current strengths/weaknesses; for each weakness, define a strategic practice item and a corresponding tactical choice for matches.

erreurs_a_eviter: Relying on tactics that your current skills can’t support.
Ignoring practice needs revealed by tactical limitations.

meta.article_title: August 15, 2011 - The Book on Your Game

the_book_on_your_game.probleme: Not knowing or being able to outline your own playing game.
causes_communes: Unclear strengths, weaknesses, and preferred patterns.
Lack of defined serve/receive/rally plans to bring strengths into play and hide weaknesses.

debutant: Outline your strengths, weaknesses, and neutral shots.
Define how you serve, return, and rally to bring strengths into play and avoid weaknesses.
intermediaire: Create a repertoire of favored options for common situations and choose among them based on opponent.
Think through how you intend to dominate a match using your specific strengths.
avance: Maintain and update a mental (or written) ‘book’ on your game as it evolves.

exercices_complementaires.description: Draft a concise ‘book’ covering strengths, weaknesses, serves, receives, rally patterns, and domination plans.

erreurs_a_eviter: Playing without a clear idea of how you intend to win points.
Failing to tailor choices to opponent using your defined repertoire.
